title: Weather Prediction Trading System
subtitle: Building an Automated Trading System with 67% Win Rate

problem.title: The Problem
problem.description: Weather prediction markets on Kalshi presented an opportunity: market prices often didn't reflect the true probability of temperature outcomes. Traders were pricing brackets based on intuition rather than calibrated forecasts, creating systematic mispricings.
challenges: Raw weather forecasts are biased and need calibration
Market prices don't always reflect true probabilities
Position sizing requires careful risk management

sections.title: Ensemble Forecasting
sections.description: Combined multiple weather models (GFS, ICON, GEM) to create a robust ensemble forecast. Each model has different strengths - GFS for long-range, ICON for European accuracy, GEM for consistency.
details: Weighted ensemble based on historical performance
Real-time API integration for live forecasts
Temperature extraction at 850mb level for accuracy

sections.title: Forecast Calibration
sections.description: Implemented seasonal bias correction and isotonic regression to transform raw forecasts into calibrated probabilities. Achieved 26% improvement in Brier score.
details: Seasonal bias correction for each city

sections.title: Edge Detection
sections.description: Compared calibrated model probabilities against market-implied probabilities. Only traded when edge exceeded threshold (typically 5-10%).

sections.title: Position Sizing
sections.description: Used Kelly Criterion for optimal position sizing based on edge and bankroll. Implemented fractional Kelly (typically 0.25-0.5) for risk management.
details: Dynamic position sizing based on confidence

results.title: Results
results.summary: The system achieved a 67% win rate and +14% ROI on live capital over 150+ trades. Key learnings included the importance of calibration, systematic edge detection, and disciplined position sizing.
learnings: Calibration is critical - raw forecasts are biased
Position sizing matters as much as edge
Market inefficiencies exist but require patience
